data.text: Idiot's Guide to Tubeless: Where to Start?

Is there an "Idiot's Guide to Tubeless" or good resource out there? I'm going to have a shop set me up tubeless and then maintain myself from there. I mostly have a ton of basic questions and concerns.
There is no shortage of YouTube videos on the subject.
data.author: Scott Hawn

data.text: With all do respect, FB is never the place to start. As stated, YouTube will guide your way.
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: There are too many videos out there, hence me asking if anyone in the group think had a good resource (like a website you’d recommend)
data.author: Eryn Pimentel

data.text:
https://youtu.be/C8OjQKJVd5o
How to go TUBELESS on Bontrager Wheels (Tubeless Setup For Trek Bikes)
youtube.com
data.author: Ken Mooney

data.text: I don't remember exactly what videos I watch to get me up to speed with modern tuneless set ups but I think I just gathered a little from many different sources and went for it. They all will basically tell you the same things. Only variables will be, choice of sealant, tape, and valves. All of which are personal choice but all will work equally as well as the others with very little discernable differences. If your rims and tires are tubeless compatible your good to proceed. My only advice is, don't get that stuff on your clothes. It'll never come out. Good luck !
data.author: Jeff Emrich

data.text: No point in going tubeless on a gravel bike. Not unless you’re running 650b with some large tires. Was tubeless and went back to tubes
data.author: Jeff Dolfinger

data.text: I am running 650b.
data.author: Eryn Pimentel

data.text: I disagree, I was running tubes on 700X42 and had multiple pinch flats, switched to tubeless and haven't had any sort of flat and have had less rotating mass which caused my bike to feel significantly lighter while the actual weight saving on a scale was minimal.
data.author: Kenneth Rieck

data.text: .. disagree ... my 700 x40 been great tubeless for years...
data.author: Dave Watson

data.text: , disagree. Halfway through an 11 day bikepacking trip with my gravel bike. Tubeless is peace of mind, my mate is running out of tubes in the meantime.
data.author: Beineán Ó hEidín

data.text: no one else has ever said this
data.author: Doug Hanna

data.text: what a garbage statement
data.author: Carl Donaldson

data.text: 15000km on 700x50c, no flats at all and trust me I ride this in place I should have my hardtail on 2.4s TUBELESS ROCKS
data.author: Ken Boutilier

data.text: I won't even ride with someone running tubes let alone ride them myself.
data.author: Dan Porter

data.text: same 110%
data.author: Tatianna Wawrzynski

data.text: Have over 20000 tubeless gravel and road miles, on 700x42's. Will never go back to tubes.
data.author: Jim Evans

data.text: Tell everyone you buggered up your own tubeless set-up without telling everyone you buggered up your own tubeless set-up.
data.author: Craig Jones

data.text: seems dumb yo.... less rotational weight, i havent gotten a flat in the 1+ ive been running tubeless(with alot of miles). keep a tube as a backup... i see no reason to go back to tubes.
data.author: Lucas Ehster

data.text: for me, I completely disagree with that. Love tubeless
data.author: David McAllister

data.text: Riding tubeless for over a year with Schwalbe 38’s and no problems. Don’t understand the issue. Mind you LBS set them Up and I don’t interfere with them.
data.author: Barry Barker

data.text: Not sure why it didn't work out for you. But there's plenty of reason for tubeless on 700c Gravel setups. My partner and I haven't been stopped by a puncture since switching. Have gotten small punctures, sealant did it's job and was able to keep rolling. It's also one of the more cost effective ways to drop weight on the wheels. And get a more comfortable ride. If running 38mm or larger tires it's highly recommend. There still some debate among those running narrow high pressure road tires. As the higher pressure makes it harder for the sealant to do it's job.
data.author: Christopher Burkhart

data.text: There’s no way you ca run the low pressures with tubes that you can with tubeless which gives you more traction as well as comfort and a lot less goathead flats as well
data.author: WarrenandJeanne Goodwine

data.text: at least you understand…. I run 35’s for the most part at 50-55psi. On another bike with 40’s I do run tubeless. I haven’t flatted yet on tubes. Lucky I guess
data.author: Jeff Dolfinger

data.text: 35mm is definitely where you could go either way. Anyone down at 28mm running 80psi and working with tubeless... I need to know what sealant they are using.
data.author: Christopher Burkhart

data.text: I run tubeless on a road bike, 25mm tyres at about 80psi. Haven't had a puncture in 20000ks. I use Effetto Mariposa Caffelatex Tyre Sealant only because it was the first one I ever bought.
data.author: Phil Johansen

data.text: Ask your LBS. If they're a good shop, they can (and should) answer your questions and cover tubeless maintenance.
data.author: Dave Chase

data.text: Are you the type that enjoys maintaining your ride? Tubeless, for all its pros does have some cons, and tubeless requires more general upkeep than tubed. But, if you're constantly popping tubes on thorns or glass, it may be worth it. I asked my shop about it, they said if I'm not getting punctures often, it's probably not worth it, so I'm still running tubes.
data.author: Preston Graham

data.text: Yes I’ve gotten flats because of glass and thorns before so trying to minimize having to deal with that. But I do not enjoy maintenance lol
data.author: Eryn Pimentel

data.text: Most resources I've seen are about set up. Not so much maintenance. Pose your questions here, I'm sure you'll get good results. Best tips I can think of include...Have all the tools and supplies you might need for maintenance and repairs. Levers, Tubeless repair kit. CO2 inflator. Valve core remover. High volume pump. Spare sealant. A sealant syringe. An air compressor makes things way easier. Top off your sealant every 6 months using the same brand sealant. Check, and top off your pressure weekly. You're gonna love it.
data.author: Scott DeBerry

data.text: Get a Dynaplug and update the sealant as recommended
data.author: Jock DeBoer

data.text: They’ll work even better with tubes
data.author: Robert Licho

data.text: Just get the Milkit stuff. Pain free.
data.author: Beineán Ó hEidín

data.text: 2bliss is the only way! Look ‘em up on YouTube lots of info there.
data.author: Chuck Cooper

data.text: Gravel City Adventure & Supply Co. in Emporia, Ks is a great resource to help you through both setup and continued support of the system.
data.author: Robert Pugh

data.text: Gotta change milk In your tubeless tires every so often. Easy maintenance. I’ve had 15 goat head thorns at ONE time Embedded in my tires. No problem. Kept riding,broke them off with my foot as I rode. Sealed up great. Buy a tubeless repair kit and learn how to use. 🤙
data.author: Craig Robinson

data.text:
Some good TY channels that cover this are Park Tool, GCN Tech, Syd Fixes Bikes, Bikepacking.com.
BIKEPACKING.com - Bikepacking Routes, Gear, Inspiration
bikepacking.com
data.author: Scott DeBerry

data.text:
I have just started my brand after 20 years and making it before it was a thing: the 6 rules may or may not help: Tubeless Setup Rules https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLHeQXmkDlrk8jxmj_gDzZj4YnOfrA_cEp
Tubeless Setup Rules
youtube.com
data.author: Christian Borrman

data.text: Not running tubeless is like running an 8track in your car and a Betamax in your living room.
data.author: Derek Meier

data.text: today happens to be the anniversary of the Betamax, in 1975.
data.author: Paul Deutsch

data.text: Happy to help. DM me and we can li k up via video or cell.
data.author: Erik Nowakowski

data.text: i just did mine for the first time. i’m running hookless rims. used some yt videos and put sealant in via the valve after i seated the tire. all i needed was a track pump and the tires seated perfect. i didnt need any tools to get the tire on either, it was so ridiculously easy. just got a valve core remover so i could put the sealant in. it was the most anticlimactic experience ever and i am a total n00b when it comes to bike stuff. if i can do it you can too!!!
data.author: Tiger Paton

data.text: That is great to hear! Any other “must have” tools you recommend?
data.author: Eryn Pimentel

data.text:
this video i found pretty helpful. my sealant didnt come with a marked syringe so i just did a little math and made marks on the side of the bottle so i could put in 30ml at a time. https://youtu.be/aWdE7b_OwAA
How To Maintain Your Tubeless Tyres | GCN Tech Maintenance Monday
youtube.com
data.author: Tiger Paton

data.text: I use this same technique with a track pump and it works like a dream I've done it on a bunch if different tyres and rims now I use mucoff valves that have a valve core remover as the dust cap
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: i honestly didnt need any! i didnt even have to take the valve out to seat the tire, though some videos recommended it as you can get more air in faster. i got the stan’s valve remover because thats what was recommended in one of the videos, and orange seal because thats the brand literally everyone i asked recommended. i didnt even need tire irons to get the tire on though some tire/wheel combos are less cooperative. just beware that there are some loud pops when the tire seats, it can be disconcerting if you aren’t expecting it!
data.author: Tiger Paton

data.text: oh very cool. now that’s a “why don’t they ALL come like that?!” kind of feature…
data.author: Tiger Paton

data.text: the only difference I do to Tigers method is I tape the rims Put the tyre back on with a tube in it pump up tyre to reseat Then I leave the tune in over night to settle the tape down Then I take the tyre off one side only and pull the tube out Add new valve Reseat tyre Inject sealant through valve core etc as tiger explained
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: it's cool also they come in some great colours to match your bike
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: how do you tell the correct tire pressure?
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: For seating the tyre or for riding?
data.author: Tom Edwards

data.text: go to the Silva website. They have a calculator that bases tire pressure on weight, riding surface and tire width
data.author: Dan Coons

data.text: i have zipp wheels so i used their calculator on their site for riding. for seating i pumped it to about 45psi and let it sit there for a couple of hours before taking the air out to add sealant
data.author: Tiger Paton

data.text: Tubeless are great until they're not
data.author: Dave Buscarello

data.text: I love everything about tubeless except the regular maintenance. Between the wife and I, there’s five bikes that require fresh sealant every 3-6 mo, and sometimes, different maintenance tasks require new tape. It’s a PITA.
data.author: Steve Trott

data.text: fresh sealant takes about 30 seconds. Unscrew valve, squeeze in sealant, replace valve.
data.author: Dave Smith

data.text: yeah, but I like to get in there and clean everything out… maybe not necessary.
data.author: Steve Trott

data.text: it’s still expensive though.
data.author: Steve Trott

data.text: I also just started doing my own tubeless setup and I have two extra wheel set's for two different bikes and it can be challenge depending on the wheels and the tires you are working with. I would say if you can get tubeless ready wheels and tire's it makes everything much easer. I have one more thing to say make sure you put your tires back on the right way and pay attention if they are bi-directional the arrow will always go on the rotor side going forward thats an easy way to remember.
data.author: Keith Mortimer

data.text: Just have a shop do it.
data.author: Mallory McGuire

data.text: Put your tire on with a tube.pump it up.break one side lose.take out tube.put in sealant.kinda put the one side back on then hit it with a CO2 cartridge
data.author: Glen Fisher

data.text: but how do you have the valve for the tube, but also the valve through the tape for tubeless at the same time if you do this?
data.author: Eryn Pimentel

data.text: you have to tape it first before you do anything and do the 🕳 for the valve then do what I said above
data.author: Glen Fisher

data.text: So you put the valve for the tube through the hole, then when you take the tube out, you put the tubeless valve in the hole? These are the little details missed in all of this 😆 But I thought the goal of the hole through the tape was to be as small as possible so air doesn’t leak around the valve?
data.author: Eryn Pimentel

data.text: Buy the Bontrager tubeless pump
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: if it's available, been sold out for a while
data.author: Alex Helling

data.text: If shop is setting up not much to it. I top up sealant about six monthly like this. Take weight off wheels by hanging bike, deflate , remove valve core, screw on injector syringe.containing 60ml sealant and inject into valve sitting at about 4/7 o'clock, screw in valve core and pump to required pressure, spin and wobble wheel. Ride.
data.author: Nick Roozenburg

data.text: Get Black Ox sealant.
data.author: John Davis

data.text: Get Fillmore valves. Expensive but worth it.
data.author: Marcos Siete

data.text: You don’t need a shop to do it lol. It’s easy. Just watch a YouTube video
data.author: Blake Herr

data.text: You are forgetting the part where I said I'm an idiot
data.author: Eryn Pimentel

data.text: Tubeless tyres are more porous than tubes, so you tend to lose air very slowly over a few days. Check pressure before every ride.
data.author: Paul Heymans
